They used to call the docks the city’s belly — raw, animal, always a little hungry. Now it smelled like iron and old coffee, with neon bleeding off wet steel and steam vents coughing out the city’s bad habits. My place sat on the backside of Crane 7, a crooked little shop between a seam-sprayed warehouse and a scrapyard that hummed with forgotten machines. In the window, rows of memory cartridges slotted like caskets. Inside, I kept the kettle on and my conscience in a drawer.

My name is Silas Vane. I broker memories. People came to me to sell a laugh they didn't want, to buy a childhood they had never had, to erase the scar tissue of a marriage that still tasted like rust. I made a living putting pieces back into people and sometimes taking them out, neat as a tailor’s stitch. There are rules — mostly unwritten — and the first one is this: know what you sell. The second is: don’t take colors you can’t see.

Evelyn Shaw came in on a rain that sounded like it was polishing the world for a different kind of truth. She was the sort of politeness that’s been worn thin by being the same polite all the time; the skin around her eyes had that soft, flaking look of someone who kept forgetting to sleep. She held herself like a person who’d misplaced the door to her life and was apologizing for the inconvenience.

“I need a recall,” she said, voice small enough to be private. “I need to remember a man I should have met at Crane 7. I keep getting… blanks. It’s important.”

She handed me a cartridge in a paper packet — pale, official-stamped. Her name printed in a neat serif. The seal was corporate: HavenTech Memory Services. People with money and troubles get polite help; poor folks get a knee to the head. The seal meant this wasn’t some casual oddity. It meant someone with ledgerbooks had been inside her head.

I ran the cartridge through the scanner while she sat watching like a child watches a clock. On the monitor the memory unfolded in slices: rain, the spit of a cigarette, the dull thrum of cranes, and then a wash — blank, corrupted frames flagged with a corporate watermark that pulsed when you tried to step over it. Not the usual degradation of a neglected memory; this was surgical. Someone had gone in and hollowed the thing out like a peach.

I touched the imprint line and it whispered back a faint signature I’d only ever seen once before in a back-alleys data sale: an obfuscation protocol used by corporate asset recovery teams. They don't just take things for their clients. They take things that might make their clients’ clients uncomfortable: witnesses, records, names that stick around like shrapnel.

“Any idea who ‘he’ was?” I asked, even though I’d already started threading the memory back through my decryptor, which is another rule broken for the right coin.

Evelyn swallowed. “I was supposed to meet him at midnight. He— he said he’d show me something. I had it in my hand before… I think it was a— a ledger. Names. Addresses. My brother’s name. It’s been gone for weeks.”

People lose small things and sometimes whole histories. This felt like the latter. The decryptor spat up a smear and then, like a stubborn seam popping, a face poked through: short hair, something about the jaw that made me think of shipwrights and dock rats. A voice — low, blurred by static — said, “Erase the witnesses. Burn the testimony.”

Then another layer unfolded, hidden under the watermark like an old tattoo. Not her memory at all, but a transfer log: timestamps, asset IDs, and — my mouth went dry when I read the sender signature — VANE TRADES. My logo, my signature, like someone had used my stamp on a warrant to sterilize a head.

“You have records of this?” Evelyn asked, searching my face for an anchor.

I lied. “I have things. Let me see the rest.”

We peeled the memory like an onion. Each layer revealed more of the dock: a night crate, a man counting off manifests, a woman with gloves and a scar on her thumb. A crate label with a name — not a person but a code: Mnemos-1124. Then a phone camera flash, a ledger page with names crossed out. Fingers pointing. It was a list of people who’d seen something that shouldn’t be seen.

“You were present when the erasure happened,” I said, more statement than question. The evidence suggested these blanks were enforced in the field, not later at a corporate purge center.

Her hands trembled. “I remember only bits. A crate. A sound. I thought I sold the memory because I was scared. I… I don’t know. Someone said they’d help me forget, and I—”

We were getting close to lines better left un-crossed. I run memory grafts for all sorts, but I’d never authorized anything like this. Had I been hired by someone to launder those witnesses? Had my equipment been used to stamp them out? The timestamp on the log matched a night I’d been elsewhere, pretending to sleep in a cheap flat. The signature matched the old wax stamp I used on legitimate deals. Someone had my tools, or my style, and they used both with surgical confidence.

That’s when the shop lights flicked. It’s never subtle when you cross the wrong ledger. The door shuddered under a weight of boots, and metal spoke in voices. Three men with the corporate outline — straight collars, faces that had been buffed on someone’s assembly line — stood in my doorway. They moved with the bland determination of men who believe the law is a machine and they are the spanners.

One of them had a gun that smelled like new promises. “Silas Vane,” he said. “HavenTech requests your cooperation.”

I looked at Evelyn. Her mouth was a cave of fear. I looked at my wall of cartridges, at the kettle that had boiled too many truths, and at the receipt book under the counter where I kept the names I liked to forget. None of it owned me yet. Maybe that’s a kind of freedom.

“Cooperate?” I asked. “You want a seat? Tea? How about not smashing my place if you’re just here to ask nicely?”

The pause was long enough for steam to sit heavy in the air. Then the shortest one moved like a piano chord. He made a reach for the console, and the room smelled like ozone for a second as circuits went hungry. I had a crowbar hidden under a rack where I kept old consciences. I used it. It made a good sound.

We scuffled — the kind you can numb yourself with after a hundred fights. No cinema heroics. Hands and knees and someone’s tie ripped for no reason. They left with a warning and a business card left like a snake skin on the floor: HavenTech Field Ops.

When the rain let up, Evelyn stayed. “There’s a storehouse they use,” she said, voice thin as thread. “They weren’t taking goods. They were taking people’s minds — the ones who could identify the ship. They… they put memories in crates, like they were merchandise. I took a picture before it was gone.” Her eyes caught mine. “You didn’t do this, did you?”

I wanted to say no cleanly, like a flat coin. Instead I said, “I don’t know.”

We tracked the asset IDs through the under-ports — a ragged net of dockworkers who remember everything and nothing. We found a video feed ripped and left in an alley, recorded by a junk cam and time-stamped three nights ago. On the grainy screen, crates were unloaded with a kind of choreographed cruelty. Names on tags. Faces. Then a hand in frame painting over the tags with solvent, the labels dissolving into a pattern of my stamp.

We put the footage where it would bite, sent it to a low-signal channel run by an ex-journalist with a sense for revenge. It ran at two in the morning and was viral by breakfast. Someone at HavenTech lost a lot of sleep. People in the city began to see their missing neighbors not as absences but as evidence.

They came for me after that. This time not in boots but in suits with apologetic smiles and vague legalities. They offered me money, pardon, a chance to tie up loose ends and keep my hands clean. They said the memory erasures were necessary. A few more people would be safe if the lists were buried. I had the option to make my trade profitable and blind. The second rule said don’t take colors you can’t see; the third should’ve been: when you smell your own mark on a crime, take a closer look.

Evelyn left with partial recall. She remembered the man’s jaw and the ledger and the way the crate smelled like someone’s name. She would never have whole clarity; the gap was engineered too deep for a single stitch. She left a paper packet on my counter with a note that read, simply: “Find them.”

I did. We scraped names out of corrupted frames and matched them with the living: a fishwife who now hummed lullabies without knowing why; a mechanic who pried open his own skull in the dark and found the smell of diesel and a child’s laugh. Each story was a half-remembered photograph, edges singed.

We exposed enough. The city turned briefly bright with shame — editorials, angry street meetings, a mayorissuing a statement about “regulated memory retrieval.” The company rearranged a few middle managers’ lives. A few low-level operatives took the fall. The public feasted on the scandal like ravenous gulls. For a while, we felt like light.

But the twist sat at the bottom of the bowl. In the last corrupted file we decrypted, under the stamp that had my name, there was a frame that showed me. My face, older maybe, handing a small sealed box to a woman with gloves and a thumb scar — the same scar in Evelyn’s recovered memory. The timestamp matched a night when I had been in a dive with a bottle and a lie. The woman looked like she could be a sister, a friend, a conspirator. The box label read Mnemos-1124.

It could be a plant. Someone with access to my logo could sew anything into the weave of these files. Or I had missed a ledger, a night, a touch that made me complicit. The city loves a clean villain because it makes the asphalt easier to sweep. I had no clean villain to hand them, only a messy possibility that my hands were not as clean as I fabled them.

I stared at that frame until the pixels bleached into a memory of my own that might or might not have been true. If my hands had built a crate, did that mean I’d been making them for the right price, or had someone used my signature like a forged coin? If you trade memories long enough, your own begins to fray at the edges.

Evelyn left a week later, carrying what she could. There’s a kind of victory in what’s left unsaid — the knowledge that some people woke up to their missing kin, that a few bureaucrats had to smell the gutter for a day. But the names we put back into the world were borrowed against other names we could not find. The city would forget again. The corporate stamps would learn a new pattern, a new way to silence.

I shut down the shop early that night and walked out to the river. Boats swung like sleeping animals. Somewhere upstream a siren scolded the night for being noisy. I pulled the crumpled frame from my drawer; the image of me handing over that box. I kept it, folded twice, like a confession tucked into the lining of a coat.

Maybe I had done it. Maybe I was being framed. Maybe memory is a market and every broker’s fingerprint ends up on the butcher’s ledger. The last rule, which I had never admitted aloud, was this: even if you sell a memory, you can’t guarantee what you’ll keep.

I lit a cigarette, watched the smoke catch the neon, and listened to the rain. The city had a new rumor, and rumors breed like mice in a pantry. Evelyn would have pieces of her brother and a ledger printed in the public feeds, enough to restart the hunt. Some people would get answers; some would get the consolation prize of knowing there once was a name to look for.

As for me, the signature on those files meant sleep would be thin and questions loud. I kept the image in my pocket and felt it like a stone. Maybe someday I’d find the original crate, the woman with the thumb scar, and the truth that fit the seams. Or maybe the truth was a neat thing that belonged to someone who knew how to hide it.

The docks breathed. The city kept its ledger, and the ledger kept a few more blanks. I folded my hands against the cold and tried to remember whether, when I first learned to trade memories, I’d promised myself I’d never let my own be for sale. The cigarette burned down to ash, and I could not tell if the glow was hope or the last light of something spent.

People vanish from the public record, and the company sells those lives back, or worse, experiments on them. That’s the money and the motive — asset recovery and silencing potential leaks before testimony can travel.

The picture was grainy — a crate, the word Mnemos-1124 stenciled on the side, and beside it a thumb-scabbed hand wiping a manifest with solvent. Evelyn had risked more than coming to me; before the blank took her, she’d stolen a photograph.

“I tore a strip of the manifest out,” she said. “I hid it in my mother’s prayer book until they came. Then it… it vanished. I remembered the crate, the ledger, I remembered hiding the slip, but not why. I think they scrubbed the witnessing.”

That was agency. Not a passive client, but a woman who’d put something in motion and been punished for it. She stayed after the lights went out and the kettle stopped humming. She told me she’d worked logistics for a contractor that handled HavenTech shipments. That was a kind of access that explains why they wanted her quiet.

That should have been enough urgency for anyone with a conscience. We hit the docks. I have friends there who remember everything and nothing, who patch together what corporate logs try to burn. I lied. I was drinking at the Anchor the night the log said the crate passed through — I even kept the rain-smeared ticket from that night in my receipt book as a poor alibi, half-a-joke to myself. But the timestamp on the manifest matched a slot where I could’ve been anywhere, including where those crates moved. The video with my stamp pushed my heart into a brackish place between guilt and being framed.

The men left a calling card on the counter: HAVENTECH FIELD OPS. The kettle tasted like iron after that.

I set up a sting. I fed the junk footage to an ex-journalist who runs a low-signal channel that people go to when they want the truth without a buffer. Evelyn did something else — she used her logistics access to slip a forged manifest into a crate’s paperwork. It was a dangerous gamble: give the company something that would force them to move their operation and expose themselves. If she’d been scrubbed for being a witness, she’d make herself useful as bait.

We timed it. The crate moved. Their field team came in tight, efficient, and correct; they stripped tags, placed a scrub on any memory cartridge they found, and left with a handful of sealed boxes. We filmed from a safe distance. The footage ran and the city woke up angry. Editors had a feast. Some mid-level suits got fired like ceremonial sacrifices. People back on the street found the missing first names of their neighbors and grieved with a public, which is better than grieving alone and without a name. For a week the ledger mattered.

You can make a headline into a life only so long before the city goes back to business. The harder part came when the last file we decrypted peeled back a frame nobody wanted: me. A night photo — the same thumb-scarred woman and a man passing a small sealed box, and the man’s face tilted in a bad light that matched my jaw. The brand on the box read Mnemos-1124. The tag on the crate in the frame carried my wax stamp.

There was a wrinkle I’d planted for myself, a line I’d kept in the receipt book as a joke that may have been a mistake: the Anchor ticket, the scribbled note on a napkin, the name of a man I’d meant to meet that night. It could be evidence of me being there — or an easy plant. Someone with my stamp and my old flat’s address could make anything look like me. The city likes a scapegoat. It also knows how to manufacture one.

Maybe I had built crates for the right price. Maybe someone forged my mark and used my taste for old methods against me. The new footage didn’t tell which. It only showed a binding moment: the box changing hands, my face in poor resolution, and my mark on the paperwork. Enough to ruin a man, not enough to hang a verdict.

Evelyn left with partial memory, which was a small mercy. She’d stolen the photograph and used the manifest like a stick to prod a nest. She’d been the one who risked her job to plant a false manifest; she knew that risk might brand her as a collaborator in the city’s eyes. Her act kept a story alive, though: a ledger with names that would not become a footnote. She’d chosen action over forgetting, paid for it, and in the bargain given me the one thing clients rarely give — a trail.

People called me a hero for a week. People called me a villain next. HavenTech tightened security, changed stamps, and shifted routes. The city learned a new pattern for how memory was moved and made invisible. I rinsed a kettle and counted receipts. The photograph I’d kept — me handing a box to a woman with a scar — lived folded in my pocket like a stone. I pulled it out sometimes and held it to the neon, trying to see if the light would tell me whether the grain showed truth or forgery.

Ambiguity is a lousy pillow for a conscience. Maybe I had been complicit. Maybe the stamp was used without my hand. Maybe Evelyn’s act of theft and planting had made her a whistle and an accessory in the same breath. The ledger had cost us a few names back and put new blanks into the world. The city would keep needing people to make trade-offs: safety against truth, profit against human pieces.

I walked the river that night and let the cigarette burn down to ash between my fingers. The docks breathed and the neon bled into the water like ink. The last line in my receipt book was empty, a promise I hadn’t quite learned to keep. I folded the photograph and put it back where it had been — against my heart, against a pocket that might hold a stone or a confession. The question of whether I’d done it — or been done to — sat there like a name waiting in a ledger that someone else might someday want to find.
